paragraphs.text:
%md
# Variables
Scala has two different types of variables. The preferred and most commonly used actually is not variable, but can only be assigned with a fixed value upon initilization. Therefore these fixed variables are more like values and declared with "val"

msg.data:
Variables

Scala has two different types of variables. The preferred and most commonly used actually is not variable, but can only be assigned with a fixed value upon initilization. Therefore these fixed variables are more like values and declared with “val”

paragraphs.text:
%md
But since sometimes you need really variable variables, Scala supports these too. They are defined usign "var".

msg.data: But since sometimes you need really variable variables, Scala supports these too. They are defined usign “var”.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
# Types
In many cases, you do not need to care about the type of a variable, since these are inferred automatically by Scala. But of course, later when declaring functions and classes, we need to specify types. Scala has the following built-in primitive types:

    Byte
    Short
    Int
    Long
    Float
    Double
    Char
    String
    Boolean
    Unit
    Null
    Nothing
    Any
    AnyRef
    
A variable with a specific type can be delcared via

    val x:Double = 12

msg.data:

val x:Double = 12

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Tuples

Tuples are very important in Scala and are used in many places.

msg.data:
Tuples

Tuples are very important in Scala and are used in many places.

t1: Int = 1
t2: (String, Int) = (a,12)
t3: (String, Int, Int) = (a,12,14)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Functions
Of course every program needs functions.

def fn(x:Int, y:Int) : Double = { return 2.0*x +  y }

fn(23, 5)

process: (value: Double, preprocess: Double => Double)Double

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Conditions

Scala supports traditional "if/then/else" conditions. In contrast to some other programming languages, "if/then/else" is an expression not a statement. This fact enables using "if" in conditional assignments, thereby helping to stick with "val" instead of "var"

msg.data:
Conditions

Scala supports traditional “if/then/else” conditions. In contrast to some other programming languages, “if/then/else” is an expression not a statement. This fact enables using “if” in conditional assignments, thereby helping to stick with “val” instead of “var”

paragraphs.text:
def my_abs(x:Int) = if (x > 0) x else -x

my_abs(3)
my_abs(-100)

msg.data:
my_abs: (x: Int)Int
res413: Int = 3
res414: Int = 100

paragraphs.text:
val x = -12
val abs_value = if (x > 0) x else -x

%md
# Pattern Matching

Scala offers a mechanism called *Pattern Matching* which is similar to "switch/case" statements in other languages. But later we will see that pattern matching is extremly more powerful and can simplify one's life dramatically.

msg.data:
Pattern Matching

Scala offers a mechanism called Pattern Matching which is similar to “switch/case” statements in other languages. But later we will see that pattern matching is extremly more powerful and can simplify one’s life dramatically.
Someone else (Kaya Kupferschmidt) with a long name

array: Array[Int] = Array(1, 2, 10)
i = 1
i = 2
i = 10

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Break Statement

There is no such thing built into the core language. But it is available via the Scala Standard Library
